Hoja1.title: Antic Teatre
Hoja1.adress: Carrer de Verdaguer i Callís, 12, 08003 Barcelona
Hoja1.summary: Cute theatre hidden in a bar, didn't understand a thing but it was a lot of fun.

Hoja1.title: Wine & Cava Tasting Experience
Hoja1.summary: Sip and swirl your way through Catalonia's famous wine, visiting 3 renowned estates to sample bold reds, crisp whites and sparkling cava. Learn about the area's rich viticultural heritage as you pair each varietal with regional cheeses and traditional appetisers.

Hoja1.title: Picasso Museum
Hoja1.summary:
The Museo Picasso houses one of the most extensive collections of artworks by the 20th-century Spanish artist Pablo Picasso. With 4,251 works exhibited by the painter, the museum has one of the most complete permanent collections of works.

Highlights of the collection include two of his first major works, The First Communion (1896), and Science and Charity (1897). In particular, the Museu Picasso reveals Picasso's relationship with the city of Barcelona, a relationship that was shaped in his youth and adolescence and continued until his death.

An unmissible event for anyone visiting this beautiful and extraordinary city.

Hoja1.itinerary_title: Family Fun at Costa Dorada PortAventura Theme Park
Hoja1.title: Port Aventura Theme Park
Hoja1.adress: Avinguda del Batlle Pere Molas, km 2, 43840 Vila-seca, Tarragona
Hoja1.summary: Long lines, but we paid for the speedy line tickets which were expensive but worth it. My kids had an absolute ball, and it's a good day trip for all family members of all ages to enjoy. Would definitely come again.

Hoja1.title: Palau Guell
Hoja1.summary: Palau Guell is a great place to start. Situated near the base of the Rambla in the Raval neighborhood, PG offers a sumptuous glimpse into Gaudi's early years.

Hoja1.title: Placa d'Espanya Train Station
Hoja1.summary: Start your journey at PI. Espanya, (enter via Creu Coberta as there are a lot of entrances and exits). You will want to start your day quite early so you can fully enjoy the journey. Catch the R5 FGC train to Manresa-Baixador, and after 22 stops, get off at MONISTROL DE MONTSERRAT. The train takes approximately 1.5 hours, and you get to enjoy the view of outer cities of Barcelona along the way.

Hoja1.title: Shop down Passeig de Gracia
Hoja1.adress: Passeig de Gracia, Dreta de L'Eixample
Hoja1.summary: Great if you need a new watch, or bag. You can look at the Gaudi buildings too.

Hoja1.title: El Cap de Barcelona
Hoja1.summary: El Cap de Barcelona is a surrealist sculpture created by American Pop artist Roy Lichtenstein for the 1992 Summer Olympics.

Hoja1.title: Museo del Fútbol Club Barcelona
Hoja1.summary: I took myself and my two kids for the Players Experience tour which has exclusive features like visiting the players changing rooms. It was my little boys birthday so we went all out. Would really recommend it, we got to walk along the pitch and the tour guide was very informative. The museum was also good.

Hoja1.title: Virreina Square
Hoja1.summary: Pretty Square

Hoja1.title: Kikibio Restaurant
Hoja1.summary: Carrer de Blai is filled with Pincho bars, so me and my friends normally spend a day walking through it, stopping at different bars and getting a beer and a pincho and having a chat. The bars I've listed is just a few, there are loads more so feel free to pick your own. Some are more expensive than others, i've tried to pick the cheapest. Perfect day for a student saving money.

Hoja1.title: Picasso Museum
Hoja1.summary:
The Museo Picasso houses one of the most extensive collections of artworks by the 20th-century Spanish artist Pablo Picasso. With 4,251 works exhibited by the painter, the museum has one of the most complete permanent collections of works.

Highlights of the collection include two of his first major works, The First Communion (1896), and Science and Charity (1897). In particular, the Museu Picasso reveals Picasso's relationship with the city of Barcelona, a relationship that was shaped in his youth and adolescence and continued until his death.

Hoja1.title: Mood Rooftop Bar
Hoja1.summary: Poached eggs are delicious, started the tour off with a simosa.

Hoja1.title: Bus Journey to Tossa de Mar
Hoja1.adress:
Estacio del Nord
Carrer d'Alí Bei, 80, 08013 Barcelona
Hoja1.summary: Take the coach to Tossa de Mar, the journey lasts aprox 1hr 45minutes.

Hoja1.title: Can Sophia
Hoja1.adress: Carrer de la Roqueta, 10, 17320 Tossa de Mar, Girona
Hoja1.summary: Good breakfast

Hoja1.title: Train to Sitges
Hoja1.adress:
You can catch the train from three central stations in Barcelona:
Estacio de Francia
Passeig de Gracia
Sants Estacio
Hoja1.summary: The train takes approximately 40 minutes, and you can enjoy the rustic, graffitti covered buildings on your way out the city.

Hoja1.title: Breakfast at Red Velvet Cafe
Hoja1.adress: Passeig de la Ribera, 8, 08870 Sitges, Barcelona
Hoja1.summary: Very cosy with nice breakfasts, lovely start to the day.

Hoja1.title: Brandenburg Gate
Hoja1.summary: Enjoy one of the most historical landmarks and touristic hubs of Berlin.

Hoja1.title: Berlin Wall East Gallery
Hoja1.summary: We walked along the whole east gallery of the Berlin wall where projects were commissioned by 118 artists to celebrate its demise.

Hoja1.title: NEMO Science Museum
Hoja1.summary: The museum is HUGE and looks like a giant ship. It has interactive science exhibits and experiments. It was a family holiday, and the kids thoroughly enjoyed playing with all the different displays. We stopped for a snack and a coffee in the museum cafe.

Hoja1.title: The Oude Church
Hoja1.summary: This ancient church is steeped in history and has stood in Amsterdam for over 800 years. Today, the church acts as a cultural centre and regularly hosts exhibitions and concerts.

Hoja1.title: The Oude Church
Hoja1.summary: This ancient church is steeped in history and has stood in Amsterdam for over 800 years. Today, the church acts as a cultural centre and regularly hosts exhibitions and concerts.

Hoja1.title: Scandinavian Embassy Cafe for Breakfast
Hoja1.summary: Scandinavian style breakfast in a unique venue.

Hoja1.title: Belém Tower
Hoja1.summary: Landmark

Hoja1.itinerary_title: A short time with Lisbon wine
Hoja1.title: Lisbon Wine Tasting Private Tour
Hoja1.summary: Private tour guide and private tastings, learn about the culture, and wine and dine at some of the best vineyards in Lisbon. It was an absolute pleasure undergoing this delectable adventure and I could not recommend it more highly.

Hoja1.title: Eiffel Tower
Hoja1.adress: Champ de Mars, 5 Avenue Anatole France, 75007 Paris, France
Hoja1.summary: Gustave Eiffel's iconic, wrought-iron 1889 tower, with steps and elevators to observation decks.

Hoja1.itinerary_title: Paris without wine is not fine.
Hoja1.title: Eiffel Tower
Hoja1.adress: Champ de Mars, 5 Avenue Anatole France, 75007 Paris, France
Hoja1.summary: Perfect introduction to Paris, the Eiffel Tower is simply a must.

Hoja1.title: The Long Hall Pub
Hoja1.adress: 51 South Great George's Street, Dublin 2, Ireland
Hoja1.summary: So tacky but great drinks

Hoja1.title: Hungarian National Gallery
Hoja1.summary:
Take your time to enjoy the splender of the exquisite art exhibitions from permanent to temporary collections, of Hungarian works from the 15th century to the modern day. 

Stop at the gallery cafe or one of the outside stalls and have a coffee and a cake and take in the stunning views from high up on the beautiful Buda Castle hill.

A truely incomparable site behond imagination.

Hoja1.title: Shoes on the Danube Bank
Hoja1.adress: Budapest, Id. Antall József rkp., 1054 Hungary
Hoja1.summary: Waterside shoe sculptures memorializing those killed at the river by a fascist party during WWII.

Hoja1.title: Tokaj Wine Country Day Trip outside Budapest
Hoja1.summary: Taste the sweet side of Hungary’s wine region on a full-day tour of Tokaj from Budapest. Led by a local guide, you'll travel through the scenic countryside famous for its dessert wine. Your trip includes stops at three wineries to taste the unique varietals of each. Listen in on the winemakers’ best secrets and take a tour of a local cellar and vineyard. You’ll also be treated to a delicious 3-course lunch, along with meat and cheese samples at the third and final winery. A day to remember and savour, just thinking about it makes my mind shiver with delight at the distinctive and yummy flavours we had the pleasure of tasting. Yum!

Hoja1.title: Roaming the Streets
Hoja1.adress:
Old Town
Staré Město
110 00 Prague 1
Czechia
Hoja1.summary: Prague has some of the most intricate and beautiful architecture I’ve ever seen.

Hoja1.title: Santiago Bernabéu Stadium
Hoja1.summary: I took myself to my first Real Madrid Match and it was phenomenal. No kids today but I know they would have loved it.

Hoja1.title: Museo Nacional del Prado
Hoja1.summary: I had a very enjoyable time at the Museo Nacional del Prado. Very informative and filled with beautiiful exhibits. Would highly recommend it, the art was just stunning.

Hoja1.title: Vatican Museums
Hoja1.summary: Multiple galleries plus the Sistine Chapel frescoes, pretty interesting.

Hoja1.title: Colosseum
Hoja1.adress: Piazza del Colosseo, 1, 00184 Roma RM, Italy

Hoja1.title: Villa Farnesina
Hoja1.adress: Via della Lungara, 230, 00165 Roma RM, Italy
Hoja1.summary:
Villa Farnesina is a suburban Renaissance villa that is probably the most underrated museum in all of Rome. It was built for Agostino Chigi, the treasurer of Pope Julius II, who commissioned Raphael (among others) to paint elaborate frescoes in the airy space. 

Raphael’s 16th century frescoes of Cupid and Psyche and the Triumph of Galatea adorn the ceiling of the loggia, or ground floor of the palazzo, and are the best known works in the villa.

Hoja1.title: Bernini’s Apollo and Daphne
Hoja1.adress: Borghese Gallery and Museum Piazzale Scipione Borghese, 5, 00197 Roma RM, Italy
Hoja1.summary: This statue will make you rethink what is humanly possible for an art genius to create. This life-sized marble statue residing within Galleria Borghese portrays Apollo clutching Daphne as she tries to escape him, precisely in the moment that her father begins her transformation into a laurel tree to save her from his grasp. Her fingers transforming into leaves are breathtakingly beautiful and demonstrate Bernini’s talent in spite of his young age.
